msItem.author: Peter Lombard
msItem.title: Sententiae
msItem.note: (fol. 2r-12ra) List of capitula for the four books 'Hic incipiunt capitula primi libri sententiarum', etc. They do not all correspond exactly with the chapter divisions in the MS.
The beginning of the text is missing.

The missing leaves contained Lib. I, D. I cap. I-III §9 (frui se debeant); Lib. I, D. XXIII cap. I § 204 (non inutilis)-cap. v § 208 (penitus nulla diversitas); Lib. I, D. XLVIII cap. II §435 (a Iudeis hic dis-) -Lib. II, D. I. cap. III § 3 (mundum quoque); Lib. II, D. IX cap. VI § 66 (hominibus forman-)-D. x cap. II § 73 (veniebat incendere); Lib. III, D. Xxx cap. I S212 (Illud multo)—§ 217 (-hit. Item Ambrosius); Lib. III, D. XXXIV cap. IV § 235 (invitus bene)-cap. VI §239 (nisi prius ille); Lib. IV, D. I cap. 1-cap. VIII §10 (-ulte erant.); Lib. IV, D. IV cap. IV. §43 (iustificari et sal-)-cap. vI § 50 (imputetur queritur); Lib. IV, D. XVI cap. IV § 162 (opriment sicut unum)-D. XVII cap. I § 166 (Item Ieronymus); Lib. IV, D. xxv beg. cap. 1-end cap. 1 § 258 (-di non sunt.); Lib. IV, D. XLVIII cap. V § 243 (Iohannes (corr. to Iohel) testatur dicens)D. XLIX cap. IV end § 440 (administratio).

There are marginal and interlinear glosses in two English hands, both probably contemporary with the text. The glosses were not systematically entered all through. There are none, e.g., between fol. 41-84v (end of Lib. 1), 99-114v, 129–137. The end of Lib. III is only sparsely annotated. The glosses include all the types discussed by J. de Ghellinck, 'Les notes marginales du Liber Sententiarum', Rev. d'hist. ecclés. 14 (1913), 511-36. The commonest are identifications of sources and cross references, and definitions of terms. Many of the glosses are closely related to, or sometimes identical with, those in MSS. Canon. Pat. Lat. 189 and New College 106 and 108, which belong to the same family as MS. Troyes 1206, the glosses of which are discussed by J. de Ghellinck, Le mouvement théologique du XIIe siècle, Bruges, 1948, pp. 353–63. Like these, our MS. frequently cites the Summa of Gandulphus of Bologna ('Gwando' or 'Gwandofus'). It follows the Troyes MS. in giving the treatise of Gandulphus 'De Eucharistia' a separate chapter numbering (fols. 203-204vb passim, cf. de Ghellinck, pp. 356-7). As in other MSS. the Glossa ordinaria on the Bible, Gratian's Decretum, Hugh of St. Victor's De Sacramentis, and the Summa Sententiarum (here attributed to Hugh) are continually cited. References to the Fathers are often found to have come from these sources and are sometimes shown to have been inaccurately quoted. On fol. 37va (Lib. 1, D. XVII cap. v § 154, on mensura) there is a reference to Peter of Poitiers and on fol. 187va (Lib. III, beg. D. xxxv), for a distinction between ‘sapientia' and 'scientia', Seneca ad Lucilium, Macrobius, and Cicero, Tusc. and Offic., are cited. Neither of these glosses are in the Canonici or New College MSS. The glossing hands also added, rather unsystematically, the section numberings and summaries of Robert Kilwardby, for which see D. Callus, 'The "Tabulae super Originalia Patrum" of Robert Kilwardby O.P.', Studia Mediaevalia in hon. R. J. Martin, Bruges, 1949, p. 264.

handDesc.handNote: Written in a university text hand, possibly in France.

decoDesc.decoNote: One painted initial survives at the beginning of book III (fol. 147): it is in pink, on a blue and pink ground with some geometrical decoration in straps of pink and decorated with spots of gold.
On fols. 2r, 4v, 7v, 9v and 12r, initials in blue and red flourished in red and blue, other initials red flourished in blue or blue in red penwork.
On fol. 1v and 2r are offsets which suggest that there may once have been a table of consanguinity at the beginning of the MS.

binding.p: Bound in N. France, probably in the last quarter of the 15th cent., in wooden boards covered with brown calf blind stamped with diagonals forming lozenge compartments in which are stamped two seals: a a pascal lamb with 'S. IEHAN DE BOIENVAL'; b a saintly bishop or abbot with cross, mitre, and halo and 's. M. DE LA MEAUFE'. Reproduced by Goldschmidt, Gothic and Renaissance Bookbindings, pl. II (front cover), XCIX, 3 (rubbings of stamps). Two metal clasps on modern leather straps.

history.provenance: The stamps on the binding suggest that the MS. once belonged to a monastery or church in N. France. There is a village called La Meauffe in Brittany, near St. Clair in the diocese of Coutances.

Throughout the MS. are a number of notes and scribbles in English hands of the late 16th-17th cents. These include: (fol. 4) 'Robert Ashton', possibly the man who matriculated at Lincoln College, Oxford in 1624 and later became a barrister at Lincoln's Inn (Foster, Alumni Oxonienses, p. 36)

(fol. 7v) 'Josias Lambert of Carton (=Carlton?) in Craven in the countye of Yorke gentleman doe alowe and command to bee alowed all and singuler.' A Josias Lamberte of Skipton in Craven, Yorks., matriculated at Trinity College, Oxford, in 1623 (Foster, p. 871)

(fol. 208) 'William Deane of Hawaorthe'; (fol. 242, 263, 266) 'Thomas Ellys'; (fol. 263) 'For as muche as I am enformed that Robert Deane of Haworthe in the countie of Yorke Clotheyer have had and stowlen(?)'. A Robert Deane of Yorks. matriculated at University College in 1586 (Foster, p. 390).
Later belonged to George Dunn of Woolley Hall near Maidenhead (bookplate): lot 486 in his sale, Sotheby's, 11-14 Feb. 1913
E. P. Goldschmidt, see his Gothic and Renaissance Bookbindings, London, 1928, no. 3 and pls. II, XCIX 3.
James P. R. Lyell, 1871–1948: bought by Lyell in December 1941 from Davis and Orioli.
history.acquisition: Chosen as one of the hundred manuscripts bequeathed to the Bodleian by Lyell in 1948.
